summary.p: [Christoph] Froschauer has conveyed Happel [Bullinger's] greetings and his commentary on Mark. Even though Bullinger expects nothing in return, Happel hopes to be able to express his gratitude. - Bullinger will learn more from Froschauer and from letters of others.

div.p: Grace and peace from the Lord.

Our Froschauer conveyed to me your many greetings and at the same time, in your name, gifted me your commentaries on Mark, for which reasons I owe you, most humane of all men, eternal gratitude for your exceptional kindness. And although your generous spirit (which wished to leave a testimony or token of your goodwill and faith towards me and expects no reward) consoles me, I will consider my life bitter unless I, in turn, send back a pledge of my respect and faith towards you and all yours - suitable to my humble fortune and not unworthy of our friendship. Meanwhile, I wish you to free me from any suspicion of rusticity and ingratitude.
Farewell with your whole household. The time does not allow me to write more; and in person, from Froschauer and from the letters of others, you will learn more, I know.
Given from Frankfurt, 12th of September, 1545. Yours with all my heart, Wigand Happel.
